question_text: Based on the provided paper content, explain the general mechanisms that cause arsenic to preferentially partition into fine particulate matter in coal flue gas during the post-combustion cooling process, focusing on the condensation and adsorption processes described.
standard_answer: Arsenic partitioning to fine particulate matter occurs during the post-combustion cooling phase as flue gas temperatures decrease. As the flue gas cools from combustion temperatures, arsenic vapor undergoes condensation and adsorption processes on available surfaces. Fine particles provide ideal surfaces for arsenic accumulation due to their high surface-to-volume ratios and prolonged suspension in the gas stream. The paper indicates that gaseous arsenic will experience adsorption, condensation, and chemical transformation as the flue gas cools. Most of the generated arsenic vapor is captured by fly ash and tends to accumulate on the surface of the smaller fly ash particles. This enrichment on fine particles occurs because smaller particles remain suspended longer in the gas stream, allowing more time for vapor-phase arsenic to contact and deposit on their surfaces through condensation and adsorption mechanisms. The transformation process involves arsenic vapor converting to solid forms that preferentially attach to the available surfaces of fine fly ash particles as temperatures decrease through the boiler and air pollution control devices.
